awd_titl_txt: Linking how the mechanics of high rate and impulse of loading to the brain leads to varying types and levels of damage to neuronal structure and function.
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Pfister, Bryan 
Proposal: 1706157 

Every fifteen seconds, someone suffers a traumatic brain injury (TBI) -- leading to over 5.3 million Americans coping with varying severity of brain injuries. Compared to severe TBI, little is known about the consequences of mild TBI or blast TBI on neuronal function that can then lead to cognitive deficits and changes in behavior. In addition, there is wide variability in patient outcomes after a TBI. Injury severity may in part depend on how the head is hit. Indeed, the mechanical nature of injury to the head varies greatly from motor vehicle accidents, falls, sports, assaults, and exposure to blasts. The cause of TBI has mostly been described in terms of tissue strains due to the brain motion in the skull. Distinctively different biomechanical insults to the head will translate to unique loading and deformation patterns throughout the brain. The project goal is to define how the mechanical loading and deformation of neuronal cells associated with motor vehicle accidents (non-impact) differ from high rate and impulse loading associated with blunt impact (sport concussion) and blast exposure (extreme rate) in terms of the effect on structure and function of neuronal cells.  With appropriate models and information establishing how biomechanics plays an important role in neuronal structure and function, the TBI community will be able to replicate injury as needed for their studies in order to better understand various injury outcomes.   This research will include the participation of engineering students at all levels, senior capstone design projects, and a summer programs for undergraduate and high school students. The PI prioritizes and has experience with including and accommodating students with disabilities.

Compared to severe forms of traumatic brain injury (TBI), little is known about the consequences of mild TBI or blast TBI on cellular properties, neural networks, and behavior -- the dysfunction at the core of cognitive deficits. Mild injuries do not show the overt tissue damage present in severe cases, and diagnoses are often missed or uncertain.  The variations in TBI are also an important biomechanical problem. The mechanical nature of injury to the head can vary greatly between motor vehicle accidents, falls, sports, assaults, and exposure to blasts.  The project hypothesizes that the magnitude, rate and impulse of the local mechanics each contribute to cause different alterations in neuronal structure and function that underlie the variety of outcomes seen in TBI patients. Neuronal and axon pathology have been well characterized in animal models from large brain deformations that are typically associated with head rotations. Accordingly, the known mechanisms of TBI have mostly been described in terms of tissue strains. Only recently has research begun exploring blunt impact and blast modes of injury, but with little focus on how the associated high rate and impulse loading causes damage at the neuronal level.  This project focuses on defining how these vastly different biomechanical loading parameters affect structure and function of the neuron, which may shed light on different mechanisms of injury that may be important to the diversity of patient outcomes in head injury.  Defining studies make use of an in vitro, 3D neuronal culture model of blast injury and an established in vitro stretch injury model to replicate strains, rates and impulses of three modes (non-impact, blunt pact and blast exposure) of injury. The specific aims are to: 1) create a dose curve of cell viability to blast exposure (vs. overpressure and impulse) in a 3D in vitro blast model; 2) investigate the importance of high strain rate and impulse loading to alterations in neuronal structure; and 3) investigate the importance of high strain rate and impulse loading on neuronal electrical activity.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.inst_street_address: 323 DR MARTIN LUTHER KING JR BLVD

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

 

There is a wide variability in patient outcome after a traumatic brain injury (TBI) as the injury depends on how the head is hit. Indeed, the mechanical nature of injury varies greatly from motor vehicle accidents, falls, sports, assaults, and exposure to blasts. The cause of TBI has mostly been described in terms of tissue strains due to the motion of the brain inside the skull. Distinctively different biomechanical insults to the head will translate to unique loading and deformation patterns throughout the brain. As engineers, we have an opportunity to contribute to the field of TBI by establishing how biomechanics plays an important role in neuronal structure and function after injury.

 

Scientific Merit

The deformation patterns of the brain from various head injuries differ in the amount of strain (percent deformation), strain rate (speed of deformation) and the duration of the deformation. In this work, we utilized injury induced intracellular calcium dysregulation since it is a major initiator of the pathological sequel after TBI. The results of this work detail how strain and strain rate both are important parameters that damage the neuronal membrane to allow pathologic levels of calcium into the cell. This work revealed for the first time that high strain rates associated with head impacts directly damages membrane ion channels. To consider the effects of deformation duration, we introduced the measures of strain impulse (area under the strain time curve) and strain power (the product of strain magnitude and strain rate) which correlate with mechanoporation of the neuronal membrane under uniaxial and biaxial stretch modalities respectively.  Most research in these areas has been isolated to the neuronal soma or axon compartments. This work distinguishes the mechanical initiation of elevated calcium dysregulation in each compartment and the individual mechanisms.

 

TBI from blast represents the extreme case of high-rate injury that is several orders of magnitude greater that for a blunt injury. Currently, blast TBI research is almost exclusively done in animal models.  This work established a blast 3D culture system, built on our experience with surrogate head models. A neuronal culture system was placed inside a liquid tight injury chamber surrounded by artificial cerebrospinal fluid. The injury chamber is mounted on an anthropomorphic neck for use in a blast simulation tube or drop tower for blunt injuries. 

 

Prolonged elevated levels of intracellular calcium after mechanical injury leads to neuronal degeneration. This work hypothesized that Store Operated Calcium Entry (SOCE), a normal cellular mechanism to restore calcium homeostasis, may perpetuate elevated intracellular calcium after stretch injury. Injuring neuronal cultures below the mechanoporation threshold, this work suggests that SOCE is a mechanism that is directly activated by mechanical stretch. These results lay the groundwork to further explore the potential mechanism for the perpetuation of calcium dysregulation that confounds the secondary injury processes in TBI. This will be the dissertation topic of a PhD student trained under this grant.

 

Chronic inflammation after TBI is a new area of research. Brain non-neuronal glial cells are believed to be a major driver of post injury brain inflammation and long-term neuronal death. Here we show that astrocytes respond to injurious levels of stretch and engage in proinflammatory cytokine production. This has major implications for long-term neuronal loss in TBI. This will be the dissertation topic of a PhD student trained under this grant.

 

Broader Impacts

This grant provided research projects and support for 6 undergraduate students and 2 PhD candidates.  One PhD candidate started on this grant as an undergraduate researcher which inspired her to pursue a PhD.  This grant also provided the opportunity for a new Assistant Research Professor to get deeply involved in undergraduate research mentoring. This led to the award of an NIH R15 with an undergraduate mentoring focus.

 

The research finding from this work have some broader impacts. In vitro modeling of TBI has contributed greatly to the understanding of neurodegenerative mechanisms related to mechanical stretch. In vitro modeling of blast TBI, however, is not well established. The model developed under this grant will allow future work with realistic blunt and blast injury recreation. The mechanical activation of intracellular processes is important to the field of mechanobiology both for physiological and injurious processes. This work identified a new intracellular mechanism that may play a role in perpetuating calcium homeostasis and will be applicable to many neurological fields and the investigation of potential therapeutic targets. Finally, chronic inflammation driven programmed cell death is a growing area of research.  In TBI, it may be a major mechanism to the accumulation of low level TBI damage as well as creating susceptibility to neurological disease such as Alzheimer’s disease. Here we show that astrocytes may be a major contributor to proinflammatory state after TBI and the perpetuation of chronic inflammation in the brain.

 


Last Modified: 02/25/2022
Modified by: Bryan J Pfister

Project Outcomes Report

 

There is a wide variability in patient outcome after a traumatic brain injury (TBI) as the injury depends on how the head is hit. Indeed, the mechanical nature of injury varies greatly from motor vehicle accidents, falls, sports, assaults, and exposure to blasts. The cause of TBI has mostly been described in terms of tissue strains due to the motion of the brain inside the skull. Distinctively different biomechanical insults to the head will translate to unique loading and deformation patterns throughout the brain. As engineers, we have an opportunity to contribute to the field of TBI by establishing how biomechanics plays an important role in neuronal structure and function after injury.

The deformation patterns of the brain from various head injuries differ in the amount of strain (percent deformation), strain rate (speed of deformation) and the duration of the deformation. In this work, we utilized injury induced intracellular calcium dysregulation since it is a major initiator of the pathological sequel after TBI. The results of this work detail how strain and strain rate both are important parameters that damage the neuronal membrane to allow pathologic levels of calcium into the cell. Most research in these areas has been isolated to the neuronal soma or axon compartments. This work distinguishes the mechanical initiation of elevated calcium dysregulation in each compartment and the individual mechanisms.
 
TBI from blast represents the extreme case of high-rate injury that is several orders of magnitude greater that for a blunt injury. Currently, blast TBI research is almost exclusively done in animal models.  This work established a blast 3D culture system, built on our experience with surrogate head models. A neuronal culture system was placed inside a liquid tight injury chamber surrounded by artificial cerebrospinal fluid. The injury chamber is mounted on an anthropomorphic neck for use in a blast simulation tube or drop tower for blunt injuries. 
 

Prolonged elevated levels of intracellular calcium after mechanical injury leads to neuronal degeneration. This work hypothesized that Store Operated Calcium Entry (SOCE), a normal cellular mechanism to restore calcium homeostasis, may perpetuate elevated intracellular calcium after stretch injury. Injuring neuronal cultures below the mechanoporation threshold, this work suggests that SOCE is a mechanism that is directly activated by mechanical stretch. These results lay the groundwork to further explore the potential mechanism for the perpetuation of calcium dysregulation that confounds the secondary injury processes in TBI. This will be the dissertation topic of a PhD student trained under this grant.

Here we show that astrocytes respond to injurious levels of stretch and engage in proinflammatory cytokine production. This has major implications for long-term neuronal loss in TBI. This will be the dissertation topic of a PhD student trained under this grant.

 

Broader Impacts

This grant provided research projects and support for 6 undergraduate students and 2 PhD candidates.  One PhD candidate started on this grant as an undergraduate researcher which inspired her to pursue a PhD.  This grant also provided the opportunity for a new Assistant Research Professor to get deeply involved in undergraduate research mentoring. This led to the award of an NIH R15 with an undergraduate mentoring focus.

 

The research finding from this work have some broader impacts. In vitro modeling of TBI has contributed greatly to the understanding of neurodegenerative mechanisms related to mechanical stretch. In vitro modeling of blast TBI, however, is not well established. The model developed under this grant will allow future work with realistic blunt and blast injury recreation. The mechanical activation of intracellular processes is important to the field of mechanobiology both for physiological and injurious processes. This work identified a new intracellular mechanism that may play a role in perpetuating calcium homeostasis and will be applicable to many neurological fields and the investigation of potential therapeutic targets. Finally, chronic inflammation driven programmed cell death is a growing area of research.  In TBI, it may be a major mechanism to the accumulation of low level TBI damage as well as creating susceptibility to neurological disease such as Alzheimer’s disease. Here we show that astrocytes may be a major contributor to proinflammatory state after TBI and the perpetuation of chronic inflammation in the brain.
